templates.template: <<SELF>> is not the <preposition> that indicates the affected subject. Look up the <noun> <<HEAD>> in the dictionary and find the appropriate <preposition>.
<<SELF>> is not the <preposition> to be used with the <intransitive verb> <<HEAD>>. You should use the <preposition> <<CORRECTED>> with the <VERB> <<HEAD>>.
<<SELF>> is not the correct <preposition> to be used with the <adjective> <<HEAD>>. Look up the <adjective> <<HEAD>> in a dictionary to learn the appropriate <preposition> to be used.

When the <verb> <<HEAD>> is used as an <intransitive verb>, <<EXPLAIN>> a <preposition> needs to precede the what is being thought about. Look up the <verb> <<HEAD>> in the dictionary to find the appropriate preposition.
When a <noun> is qualified by another <noun> that follows, a <preposition> is necessary between the two nouns. Think of the most common <preposition> of association.
While the <conjunction> <<HEAD>> is used as it is when preceding a <clause>, the <preposition> <<SELF>> is necessary when preceding a <noun phrase>.
As the <verb> <<HEAD>> is a <transitive verb>, the <object> does not need to be preceded by a <preposition>.

other-templates.template: When the <to infinitive> <<SELF>> follows the <verb> <<HEAD>>, you should use the <-ing form> <<CORRECTED>> instead.
Since the <verb> <<SELF>> is a <transitive verb>, the <object> does not require a <preposition>.
